root.prompt: A runner develops throat tightness, urticaria, hypotension, and shortness of breath after a race. What do you do first?

info.narration: Cross-country meet setting. You have oxygen, epinephrine auto-injector, IV supplies, and EMS ETA 10-12 minutes.

choices.label: A
choices.text: Give IM epinephrine immediately, call EMS, and position supine with legs elevated.
choices.feedback: Correct. Epinephrine is first-line and time critical.

next.prompt: Two minutes later symptoms improve but not fully resolved. What next?

choices.label: A
choices.text: Prepare IV access, continue monitoring, and be ready for repeat IM epinephrine if symptoms persist.
choices.feedback: Correct. Continue active management and handoff planning.

next.prompt: Patient stabilizes and is transferred to the ED with complete EMS handoff.

choices.label: B
choices.text: Stop interventions and discharge to family because symptoms improved.
choices.feedback: Unsafe. Biphasic or recurrent reactions can occur.

next.prompt: Patient worsens after premature discharge and requires emergency re-intervention.

choices.label: B
choices.text: Give only albuterol and oxygen first, then wait for EMS.
choices.feedback: Incomplete. This does not treat systemic anaphylaxis adequately.

next.prompt: Symptoms progress while definitive epinephrine treatment is delayed.

choices.label: C
choices.feedback: Incorrect initial management for airway and hypotensive anaphylaxis.

next.prompt: Airway and perfusion worsen due to delayed epinephrine.
